snippet.textDisplay: York has two platform 0 candidates, both south facing bays. Formally numbered 1 and 2. Platform 2 has a platform and canopy but no track, lost at time of electrification, platform 1 has a platform and canopy last used for motorail, now used as car park. Probably survive due to the station being listed.
snippet.textOriginal: York has two platform 0 candidates, both south facing bays. Formally numbered 1 and 2. Platform 2 has a platform and canopy but no track, lost at time of electrification, platform 1 has a platform and canopy last used for motorail, now used as car park. Probably survive due to the station being listed.

snippet.textDisplay: I used to work on the Royal Mail platform in Tonbridge years ago. It was part of the then Tonbridge Mail Center. After Royal Mail retired the TPO's we stopped using the platform. It is still there and can be viewed from a couple of near by road bridges.

snippet.textDisplay: On the question of negative platform numbers and the possible signage problem of confusing a minus sign with a hyphen, what about adopting the accountant's way of getting around this? In the olden days, they put negative figures in red (positives being standard black), hence the expression ”in the red” which some of us know all too well. When photocopying came in, all colours appeared a shade of grey, so the convention was replaced by putting negative numbers in parentheses, minus 1 being easily confused with 1 owing to defects with the original handwriting and copying process, and people quickly reading the copies not recognizing the significance of a minus sign. This is exactly the problem you identified. So Platform -1 could be signed “Platform (1)” ; people would not fail to notice at least that this is not the same as “Platform 1” and would ask why the number is in parentheses if they did not know. If you wanted to emphasize it, you could use red for the script as well.
snippet.textOriginal: On the question of negative platform numbers and the possible signage problem of confusing a minus sign with a hyphen, what about adopting the accountant's way of getting around this? In the olden days, they put negative figures in red (positives being standard black), hence the expression ”in the red” which some of us know all too well. When photocopying came in, all colours appeared a shade of grey, so the convention was replaced by putting negative numbers in parentheses, minus 1 being easily confused with 1 owing to defects with the original handwriting and copying process, and people quickly reading the copies not recognizing the significance of a minus sign. This is exactly the problem you identified. So Platform -1 could be signed “Platform (1)” ; people would not fail to notice at least that this is not the same as “Platform 1” and would ask why the number is in parentheses if they did not know. If you wanted to emphasize it, you could use red for the script as well.

snippet.textDisplay:
The London Bus network has a few Stop I's, and a lot more Stop J's (for the engineers/python programmers). It also has Stop H's, I's, J's & K's to please the quaternionists.
That's the closest you'll get to imaginary platforms though. Even the Waterloo Easts & New Crosses won't help you. Their platforms only go up to Platform D.
D, a letter that even the most esoteric sciences using the most befunged computer programming language won't use for their imaginary unit.
snippet.textOriginal:
The London Bus network has a few Stop I's, and a lot more Stop J's (for the engineers/python programmers). It also has Stop H's, I's, J's & K's to please the quaternionists.
That's the closest you'll get to imaginary platforms though. Even the Waterloo Easts & New Crosses won't help you. Their platforms only go up to Platform D.
D, a letter that even the most esoteric sciences using the most befunged computer programming language won't use for their imaginary unit.

snippet.textDisplay: I live in Gravesend. It used to be a station with a Platform one and two, two lines passed through the middle without platforms, so the platforms were loops off of the mainline. When the re-developed the station to increase platform length to 12 carriages, they essentially took out the up main line, put a platform where it used to be and named it one. Original platform one became a bay platform lengthened and called platform zero and platform two was also lengthened. The main reason they numbered them this way was to avoid passenger confusion I think, everyone knows one is for London and two is for Country. All stopping services via Sidcup to CHX and Bexelyheath to Victoria terminate on zero. See this picture for old station: https://s0.geograph.org.uk/geophotos/03/61/47/3614715_6cedd8b5.jpg
snippet.textOriginal: I live in Gravesend. It used to be a station with a Platform one and two, two lines passed through the middle without platforms, so the platforms were loops off of the mainline. When the re-developed the station to increase platform length to 12 carriages, they essentially took out the up main line, put a platform where it used to be and named it one. Original platform one became a bay platform lengthened and called platform zero and platform two was also lengthened. The main reason they numbered them this way was to avoid passenger confusion I think, everyone knows one is for London and two is for Country. All stopping services via Sidcup to CHX and Bexelyheath to Victoria terminate on zero. See this picture for old station: https://s0.geograph.org.uk/geophotos/03/61/47/3614715_6cedd8b5.jpg

snippet.textDisplay: Hull Paragon has an unofficial platform 0. And unofficial platforms -1 and -2, if you're counting backwards! They're just used as sidings these days but they used to be used for freight and were originally built for European emigrants on their way to the USA! They don't count for your purposes as they're not used for passengers any more but still interesting!
snippet.textOriginal: Hull Paragon has an unofficial platform 0. And unofficial platforms -1 and -2, if you're counting backwards! snippet.textDisplay: Gravesend and Rainham both came about as part of the Thameslink program. The previous half hourly Charing Cross - Gillingham semi fast were replaced by Luton - Rainham Thameslink trains. With the associated timetable changes, neither station could manage with only two platforms (the Gravesend terminating trains used to reverse in platform 1 as was, necessitating Gillingham and high speed services to use 2 in both directions). There are over bridges as each end of Gravesend, and all Thameslink stations need to be 12 car, and the junctions needed to run platform 2 in both directions wouldn’t fit.
snippet.textOriginal: Gravesend and Rainham both came about as part of the Thameslink program. The previous half hourly Charing Cross - Gillingham semi fast were replaced by Luton - Rainham Thameslink trains. With the associated timetable changes, neither station could manage with only two platforms (the Gravesend terminating trains used to reverse in platform 1 as was, necessitating Gillingham and high speed services to use 2 in both directions). There are over bridges as each end of Gravesend, and all Thameslink stations need to be 12 car, and the junctions needed to run platform 2 in both directions wouldn’t fit.

snippet.textDisplay:
Why do some stations add a platform 1A instead of 0?
Bridgend, for example, wedged a 1A alongside an existing platform 1 in 2005
snippet.textOriginal:
Why do some stations add a platform 1A instead of 0?
Bridgend, for example, wedged a 1A alongside an existing platform 1 in 2005

snippet.textDisplay: There is a platform zero at Lidcombe station in Sydney. It is only used by the Olympic Park shuttle, but is busy thanks to the increasing number of people who live and work there now. Obviously during sporting events, concerts and the Easter Show it is incredibly busy. The other five platforms existed before the 2000 Olympics so platform 0 it became.
snippet.textOriginal: There is a platform zero at Lidcombe station in Sydney. It is only used by the Olympic Park shuttle, but is busy thanks to the increasing number of people who live and work there now. Obviously during sporting events, concerts and the Easter Show it is incredibly busy. The other five platforms existed before the 2000 Olympics so platform 0 it became.

snippet.textDisplay: Three Bridges? I know there's always been a lengthy stub of a loading bay opposite Platform 1,  I don't think it's ever been put in passenger service as a platform..it used to have a Platform 6 though,  a bay platform next to Platform 5, terminus for the old East Grinstead branch.
snippet.textOriginal: Three Bridges? snippet.textDisplay: We have a platform 0 or O in Australia, it is at Lidcombe Station in Sydney's west, it was originally built for the Sydney 2000 Olympic games (knowen then as the sprint platfrom and smetines is still called that today and the station signage reflects both names of the platform. Lidcombe is still used and a major interchange for Sydney Olympic park for the people who now live there and visitors to major sporting and public events to transfer onto Olympic park services running every 10 minutes from early till late 7 days a week. It's is one of the most successful Olympic park rail networks still in operation in the world and is about to get connected to a new metro system in the mid 2020's.
snippet.textOriginal: We have a platform 0 or O in Australia, it is at Lidcombe Station in Sydney's west, it was originally built for the Sydney 2000 Olympic games (knowen then as the sprint platfrom and smetines is still called that today and the station signage reflects both names of the platform. Lidcombe is still used and a major interchange for Sydney Olympic park for the people who now live there and visitors to major sporting and public events to transfer onto Olympic park services running every 10 minutes from early till late 7 days a week. It's is one of the most successful Olympic park rail networks still in operation in the world and is about to get connected to a new metro system in the mid 2020's.

snippet.textDisplay:
The Cardiff one was a disgrace built without disabled access at a major city station. My elderly parent unable to do the stairs, they had to advise us to get a different train to Newport (meaning lucky we were there in time to!) + change there. No mention in the video of fixing this - you still only mentioned the stairs as access to it.
The Haymarket one simply proves it a disgrace not to be called Edinburgh Haymarket. Take a train into a city + have it leave you at a well centrally-located station not bearing the city's name!
snippet.textOriginal:
The Cardiff one was a disgrace built without disabled access at a major city station. My elderly parent unable to do the stairs, they had to advise us to get a different train to Newport (meaning lucky we were there in time to!) + change there. No mention in the video of fixing this - you still only mentioned the stairs as access to it.
The Haymarket one simply proves it a disgrace not to be called Edinburgh Haymarket. Take a train into a city + have it leave you at a well centrally-located station not bearing the city's name!

snippet.textDisplay: I'm pretty sure that the platform 0 at King's Cross was just to make it so there was no combined platform 9 & 10, so kids would stop knocking themselves unconscious running into a brick pillar, looking for platform 9 3/4. I took a train in October, from platform 9 (shared with 8, not 10). Odd coincidence... I was going to Potters Bar!

snippet.textDisplay:
Ayyy Rainham! Absolutely no idea why it has a platform 0, and I always wonder every time I go there.

Thameslink trains always leave from platform 0. They didn’t before, but Thameslink replaced the Southeastern Gillingham to Charring Cross train from 2018 (roughly).

snippet.textDisplay: I know of a platform 0 at Lidcombe station in the western Suburbs of Sydney. I been there numerous times especially for a cosplay conventions and trains on that platform is a bay platform there and most of the trains on the Olympic Park train Line which is between Lidcombe and Olympic Park stations arrive and depart from platform 0. Despite sometimes and as a fursuiter would much prefer the Sydney Central to Olympic Park as I only need to catch 2 trains from The Newcastle Interchange to Strathfield then straight to Olympic Park. Which rarely in service and that is only for State of Origin, The royal easter show and the other nrl games. But most of the time, to get to Olympic Park by train, I had to catch the train to Lidcombe on the western suburbs lines from Strathfield for a train to Olympic Park but to do that, I had to change at Lidcombe and get to platform 0 to get to Olympic Park station by train.
snippet.textOriginal: I know of a platform 0 at Lidcombe station in the western Suburbs of Sydney. I been there numerous times especially for a cosplay conventions and trains on that platform is a bay platform there and most of the trains on the Olympic Park train Line which is between Lidcombe and Olympic Park stations arrive and depart from platform 0. Despite sometimes and as a fursuiter would much prefer the Sydney Central to Olympic Park as I only need to catch 2 trains from The Newcastle Interchange to Strathfield then straight to Olympic Park. Which rarely in service and that is only for State of Origin, The royal easter show and the other nrl games. But most of the time, to get to Olympic Park by train, I had to catch the train to Lidcombe on the western suburbs lines from Strathfield for a train to Olympic Park but to do that, I had to change at Lidcombe and get to platform 0 to get to Olympic Park station by train.

snippet.textDisplay: I lived in Gravesend for about 10 years and used the station everyday (there was no Platform 0 at the time), but then in 2010, I moved back to my home town of Stockport, where there was a Platform 0 built several years ago, during the station renevation, for a potential Metrolink(tram) line that never happened (or so was the rumour).  When I saw the vid for Platform 0, I was expecting Stockport, but not Gravesend to feature!  Can I claim the prize for 2 home Platform 0 stations? ;P Looking forward to part 2!
snippet.textOriginal: I lived in Gravesend for about 10 years and used the station everyday (there was no Platform 0 at the time), but then in 2010, I moved back to my home town of Stockport, where there was a Platform 0 built several years ago, during the station renevation, for a potential Metrolink(tram) line that never happened (or so was the rumour).  When I saw the vid for Platform 0, I was expecting Stockport, but not Gravesend to feature!  Can I claim the prize for 2 home Platform 0 stations? ;P Looking forward to part 2!
